channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: One Photo of a Syrian Child Caught the World’s Attention. These 7 Went Unnoticed.
item.description: Millions around the world now know of Omran Daqneesh, a 5-year-old Syrian boy injured in an airstrike. He isn’t alone.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Iraq Executes Dozens for 2014 Massacre by ISIS
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces on Sunday escorted one of the 36 men sentenced to death in the mass killing of Shiite military personnel at an air base in 2014.
item.description: Thirty-six men were hanged in connection with the group’s killing of 1,700 Shiite military personnel, despite concerns over the country’s criminal justice system.
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Ethiopian Marathoner’s Protest Puts Him at Odds With His Government
item.media:description: Feyisa Lilesa of Ethiopia, who won the silver medal in the men’s marathon at the Rio Olympics, during an award ceremony on Sunday.
item.description: Feyisa Lilesa, the Olympic silver medal winner, said his gesture at the finish line in Rio de Janeiro could get him killed if he returned home.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Syria’s Horrors Visit Turkey Again as Bomber Attacks Kurdish Wedding
item.media:description: Mourners at a funeral on Sunday for victims of an attack on a wedding party the previous night that left at least 51 dead in Gaziantep, Turkey.
item.description: The suicide attack, which killed more than 50, is the deadliest in a string of bombings in Turkey as the war in Syria spills over the border.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: More of Kremlin’s Opponents Are Ending Up Dead
item.media:description: The funeral of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a Putin opponent who died of radioactive polonium-210 poisoning in London in 2006.
item.description: Mysterious deaths and close calls have some opposition figures worried that political murder is resurgent in Russian foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: After Olympics, Rio Is Altered if Not Reborn
item.media:description: Military police personnel patrolling the route of the Olympic torch relay in a suburb of Rio de Janeiro two days before the Summer Games.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: The Olympics have often been seen as a sop to corporate interests, but experts say these Games pushed long-desired municipal projects to fruition in Rio.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Paralyzed Afghan, His Family Ripped Apart, Bears Pain of Perpetual War
item.media:description: Ezzatullah Khan was paralyzed by a mortar shell that killed his father, a brother, his wife and a daughter in Helmand Province.
item.media:credit: Abdul Khaliq for The New York Times
item.description: Raw numbers of the dead and wounded and displaced cannot fully gauge the cost to families forever changed, struggling to cope with daily loss and indignity.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Afghan Troops Hold Off the Taliban in Kunduz
item.description: Residents fled as insurgents advanced on the city after capturing the nearby Khanabad district.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Suicide Bombing Kills at Least 20 in Somalia
item.description: Militants struck a market in the town of Galkayo and then stormed a government building and engaged in gun battles with security forces.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and HUSSEIN MOHAMED

item.title: English Village Becomes Climate Leader by Quietly Cleaning Up Its Own Patch
item.media:description: Garry Charnock near some of the many solar panels in Ashton Hayes, England. Mr. Charnock, a former journalist, started the town’s emissions-reduction effort about 10 years ago.
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Dalziel for The New York Times
item.description: In Ashton Hayes, residents have banded together to cut greenhouse emissions with solar panels, wine-and-cheese nights and no politicians.
item.dc:creator: TATIANA SCHLOSSBERG

item.title: Blackpool Journal: A Once-Declining British Resort Town Sees New Life, Post-Brexit
item.media:description: Amusements on one of Blackpool’s piers. The British coastal city is trying to reinvent itself as a seaside resort for the modern age.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Seaside Blackpool is trying to reinvigorate itself for the modern age, and with fewer Britons vacationing abroad, things are looking up.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: China Helps Aung San Suu Kyi With Peace Talks in Myanmar
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi of Myanmar in Beijing on Thursday. China has persuaded rebel groups to join a peace conference she is convening this month.
item.description: By nudging ethnic rebel groups to participate in a peace conference, China is also aiming to clear the way for commerce across its southern border with Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and WAI MOE

item.title: ‘Night Tube,’ a First for London, Brings All-Night Service to Two Subway Lines
item.media:description: Passengers descending into the Oxford Circus station in central London on Friday night.
item.description: A new 24-hour weekend service opened to the delight of late-night crowds. “People were cheering, ‘Night Tube!’ It seems to be the buzz,” a Tube worker said.
item.dc:creator: PAULINE BOCK

item.title: Poverty, Drought and Felled Trees Imperil Malawi Water Supply
item.media:description: Villagers often use wood to bake clay bricks in the Dzalanyama Forest Reserve near Lilongwe, the capital of Malawi, which is experiencing serious water and power shortages. The depletion of the forest has heightened worries.
item.description: The practice of depleting the forest for precious fuel during hard times has been taking a toll at taps in the capital city, Lilongwe.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: North Korea Says Diplomat Who Defected Is ‘Human Scum’
item.description: A statement said Thae Yong-ho, the No. 2 person in the London embassy, had fled to South Korea rather than face punishment for various crimes.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Pramukh Swami Maharaj, Whose Hindu Sect Became Largest in U.S., Dies at 94
item.media:description: Pramukh Swami Maharaj, center, in Ahmedabad, India, in 2012. In 1971, he became the spiritual leader of the Hindu sect known as BAPS, which he helped expand throughout the world.
item.description: He established more than a thousand temples around the world for BAPS, the Bochasanwasi Akshar Purushottam Swaminarayan Sanstha sect.
item.dc:creator: AYESHA VENKATARAMAN

item.title: Ernst Nolte, Historian Whose Views on Hitler Caused an Uproar, Dies at 93
item.media:description: Ernst Nolte in 2002. He suggested that Nazism was a logical response to the “existential threat” of the Russian Revolution.
item.description: Professor Nolte, a respected German scholar of fascism, suggested in a 1986 essay that Nazism had been a logical response to the “existential threat” of the Russian Revolution.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: What in the World: Here’s a New Angle on the Shape of the World
item.description: An Australian statistician has devised a method to rank the world’s nations by how rectangular they are, with Egypt at the head of the class.
item.dc:creator: JAKE DOHERTY

item.title: What in the World: What’s That on Your Bumper? A Hairy Kind of Car Insurance
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photos by Bruno Ferrari, Cammep, ArtHeart/Shutterstock
item.description: Ponytails are attached to taxis for strength and good fortune in West Africa. Religious icons are also popular blessings for safe travel.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Saudi Arabia Kills Civilians, the U.S. Looks the Other Way
item.media:description: A food factory hit by a Saudi-led coalition, killing workers and destroying the building in Sanaa, Yemen, last week.
item.description: Even after a series of deadly attacks that killed Yemeni civilians, Washington’s support remains unwavering.
item.dc:creator: SAMUEL OAKFORD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: I Criticized the Olympics. That Doesn’t Make Me a Traitor.
item.media:description: People in a nearby favela watched fireworks exploding during the opening ceremonies of the Rio 2016 Olympic Games.
item.description: In Brazil, many of us are so obsessed with how the outside world sees us that we won’t recognize our own faults.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: When Women Fight ISIS
item.media:description: Kurdish fighters in Tal Hamis, Syria, after it was freed from Islamic State control last year.
item.media:credit: Massoud Mohammed/Barcroft Media, via Getty Images
item.description: Feminists have typically opposed war, but taking up arms is one way for women to defend their communities and to define their place in them.
item.dc:creator: MEREDITH TAX
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Nigeria Is Freeing Children From Boko Haram, Then Locking Them Up
item.media:description: Displaced people taking shelter from the rain at a camp in Maiduguri, Nigeria, in June.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: Civilians, and even infants, are ending up in military detention centers as Nigeria holds people it suspects of being sympathizers of the Islamist extremist group.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: A Foreign Correspondent’s Day at the Beach
item.media:description: Tourists at a beach in Tulum.
item.media:credit: Reinhard Dirscherl/ullstein bild, via Getty Images
item.description: Even in the wildly popular beach town of Tulum on the Yucatán Peninsula, menace can lurk just beneath the surface.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Skala Sikaminias Journal: Greek Villagers Rescued Migrants. Now They Are the Ones Suffering.
item.media:description: The keeper of the main church in Skala Sikaminias, Lesbos, looked out to sea. Some villagers say that when they look at the horizon, they often think that another refugee boat is coming.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: The island of Lesbos was ground zero for refugees flooding across the Aegean. A year later, the imprint of that experience still affects one village that tried to help.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
